results.ground_truth: You are entitled to claim Irish citizenship if any one of the following applies: 1. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland before 1 January 2005 2. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland after 31 December 2004 and any of the following applies to you: One (or both) of your parents was Irish or entitled to be an Irish citizen or a British citizen at the time of your birth One (or both) of your parents was an Irish or British citizen and died before you were born One (or both) of your parents was entitled to live in Ireland or Northern Ireland without any restriction on their period of residency One (or both) of your parents was legally resident on the island of Ireland for 3 out of the 4 years immediately before your birth (this does not include residence on a student visa, or residence while awaiting an international protection decision or residence under a declaration of subsidiary protection) 3. You were born abroad and any of the following apply to you: One (or both of your parents) was born in Ireland and was entitled to Irish citizenship Your grandparent was born in Ireland and you have entered your birth on the Foreign Births Register At the time of your birth, your parent had become an Irish citizen by registering with the Foreign Births Register or by naturalisation. You must register your birth with the Foreign Births Register before obtaining Irish citizenship. 4. You were born in Ireland and are not entitled to be a citizen of any other country.

Q: What criteria do I need to meet to qualify for unemployment benefits in Ireland?
A: You must be under 66 years of age, or under 70 years and deferring your State Pension (Contributory), be unemployed (you must be unemployed for at least 4 days out of 7), have had a substantial loss of employment and as a result be unemployed for at least 4 days out of 7 (this does not apply to casual workers and part-time fire fighters), be capable of work, be available for and genuinely seeking work, and have enough social insurance (PRSI) contributions.

Example 3:
Q: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?
A:
You may become a citizen of Ireland through naturalization based on family ties, residency requirements, or birth within the state, with certain conditions including having lived in Ireland for at least five years before applying, being able to demonstrate knowledge of the Irish language and culture, and passing an English test if applicable. To apply for citizenship, you typically need to fill out an application form, submit supporting documentation such as birth certificates and passport copies, and undergo an interview by an officer from the Department of Foreign Affairs. There are also specific eligibility criteria depending on whether you were born in Ireland, outside but with Irish parents, or through adoption. The process can vary slightly based on these factors, so it's important to check the latest guidelines from the Department of Justice and Equality for detailed information. For example, individuals who were born abroad to Irish parents would require additional documentation proving their Irish ancestry. This comprehensive approach ensures fairness and accuracy in determining citizenship status, reflecting the values of inclusivity and equality embodied in the Irish Constitution.

results.ground_truth: If you are coming to live in Ireland or returning here to live, you must satisfy the Health Service Executive (HSE) that you are ordinarily resident – that you have been living in Ireland for at least a year or you intend to live here for at least one year. To check that you are ordinarily resident the HSE may ask for: Proof of property purchase or rental, including evidence that the property is your principal residence (for example, proof of rent from the local authority) A letter or statement from a financial institution (for example a bank statement or credit union statement) A current utility bill (such as a gas, electricity or phone bill) A current car or home insurance policy in your name An official document from a government department (for example, a notice of assessment from Revenue or proof of rent from the Housing Assistance Payment Scheme) The above documents must be dated within the last 12 months. Any person, regardless of nationality, who is accepted by the HSE as being ordinarily resident in Ireland is entitled to either full eligibility (Category 1, medical card holders) or limited eligibility (Category 2) for health services.

Q: What is ordinary residence?
A:
Ordinary residence refers to the place where someone has their usual home and spends most of their time living there. This typically includes areas such as their primary workplace, school, or other significant life activities. It implies a long-term commitment and presence, distinguishing it from temporary visits or occasional stays. In legal contexts, this term can vary by jurisdiction but generally indicates the location where a person considers themselves to reside permanently. For instance, a person who works full-time in Dublin might consider themselves to have an ordinary residence there despite visiting other locations during weekends or holidays. Understanding ordinary residence helps in determining which country's laws will govern certain matters related to residency, taxation, and citizenship.

results.ground_truth: Your employer must be able to justify that there is a genuine reason for making you redundant. A genuine redundancy is one where your employer has a real business reason to make you redundant. Reasons for redundancy include: Financial difficulties within the business: for example, your employer needs to cut costs and this means staff numbers must be reduced. Lack of work: for example, your employer no longer needs or has a reduced need for employees with your skills or new technology has made your job unnecessary. Reorganisation within the business: for example, your employer has decided to carry on the business with fewer or no staff or the job you do no longer exists. Business closure: the business is closing down or moving.

Q: What counts as genuine redundancy?
A:
Genuine redundancy means that the employer has no other reason to keep you employed except your own decision to leave. This could include being given notice by your employer, having your contract terminated due to poor performance, or being laid off due to restructuring. It also includes situations where you are asked to take voluntary redundancy but choose to accept it because you believe it is in your best interest to move on professionally or personally. In all cases, your decision to leave should be based on a personal choice rather than external factors such as job insecurity, financial hardship, or lack of alternative employment opportunities. The key characteristic is that you made a conscious decision to resign voluntarily.

In summary, genuine redundancy involves making a deliberate choice to leave the position despite any potential negative consequences. To qualify, you must be offered formal termination or express a desire to resign. Your departure should align with your career goals or personal circumstances.

results.ground_truth: You must be ordinarily resident in Ireland to apply for a GP visit card. This means that you are living in Ireland and intend to live here for at least one year. You will qualify for a GP visit card with no means test if you are: Aged under 8 (see GP visit cards for children) Aged over 70 Getting Carer’s Benefit or Carer’s Allowance, at full or half-rate If you are aged under 70, your income is assessed by the HSE to see whether you qualify for a GP visit card. See below for information about the HSE basic rates of income.

results.ground_truth: A Police Certificate is an official statement about you issued by An Garda Síochána. It is used by people who have lived in Ireland and want to work or study abroad. It is required by some foreign authorities. A Police Certificate states your: Name Address Date of birth Criminal record in Ireland (this does not include adult cautions) A Police Certificate is normally valid for 1 year. You should also note that the Irish spent convictions legislation cannot be used to prevent disclosure when you are required to disclose information about your criminal convictions to another state.

results.ground_truth: Each local authority maintains the Register of Electors for its area. To be included in the Register of Electors, you must: Be at least 18 years old Be ordinarily resident at an address in Ireland If you are homeless or have no address, you can still register to vote by stating that you have ‘no fixed address.’ Read more about being homeless and registering to vote. If you have more than one address, you should give the address where you want to be registered. You can only be registered at one address. You can register to vote: Online at checktheregister.ie By filling in an application form If you do not give a PPS number, you must get your form and ID witnessed at a local Garda station or your local authority.

results.ground_truth: The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant provides funding so you can refurbish vacant and derelict homes. It can also be used to renovate vacant and derelict properties that have not been used as residential properties before. However, this only applies if the non-residential properties were used for commercial or public use before and now have the correct planning permission. You can get the grant if you are refurbishing the vacant property so you can live there, or so you can rent the property out. You can get a grant of up to €50,000 to renovate a vacant property and up to €70,000, if the property is derelict. You can get more if you are living on an off-shore island. And, there is an additional grant for expert conservation advice if you are refurbishing a vacant traditional farmhouse. The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is funded by the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage through the Croí Cónaithe (Towns) Fund and you apply to your local authority. If you have questions about the grant or want to know if your property qualifies, you can: Read the FAQs about the grant Contact the Vacant Homes Officer in your local authority Contact the Housing Agency's Vacancy Helpline on vacancycampaign@housingagency.ie You can also find information on how to re-use old and vacant buildings in the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage’s Bringing Back Homes (pdf) manual.

results.ground_truth: If you are sick while you are on annual leave, you should get a medical certificate from your GP (doctor) as soon as possible to cover the days you were sick. Give the medical certificate to your employer as soon as you return to work. This way, the sick days will not count as annual leave, and you can take your annual leave at a later date. Your employer cannot make you to take annual leave for time you were on certified sick leave.

results.ground_truth: Generally, your landlord can only end a tenancy after the first 6 months if: You do not comply with the obligations of the tenancy, for example, by not paying your rent on time The property is no longer suited to your needs, for example, if it is too small The landlord intends to sell the property within 9 months. Q: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?
A:
You can end a tenancy after the first 6 months if there has been no mutual agreement between both parties regarding the termination date; either party has breached the terms of the lease by failing to pay rent, cause damage to property, or breach any other clause outlined in the lease agreement; the landlord has given notice of their intention to terminate the tenancy; or the tenant has vacated the premises without the landlord's consent, despite having paid all outstanding rent. In such cases, the landlord may seek legal action against the tenant to recover possession of the property. If the tenant wishes to continue living in the property, they should contact the landlord to discuss alternative arrangements before taking further steps.

results.ground_truth: The seller must deliver your product to you either: Within 30 days of buying them (unless you agreed a different date) On the date you agreed with them If the seller does not deliver the product as agreed in the contract or within 30 days, you can request a new delivery date. You can insist that all items you bought in the one transaction are delivered at once. The seller cannot make you accept deliveries in instalments. You can end the contract if: The seller cannot or refuses to deliver within the new time frame you request A new delivery date is no longer suitable for you, for example, you needed the product for a specific date or event You must tell the business you are using your right to end your contract for non-delivery. results.ground_truth: To adopt a child, you must be at least 21 years of age and resident in Ireland. If you are adopting the child as a couple, and one of you is the child’s mother or father or relative, only one of you must be at least 21. There is no upper age limit for adoptive parents. You can adopt if you are: A married couple living together A couple living together in a civil partnership A couple cohabiting together (living together and in a committed relationship) for at least 3 years The mother, father or relative of the child (relative meaning a grandparent, brother, sister, uncle or aunt of the child, and/or the spouse of any such person; the relationship to the child being traced through the mother or the father) If you are a sole applicant (applying for adoption on your own), and you do not fall into any of the categories listed above, you may only adopt if the Adoption Authority of Ireland is satisfied with the particular circumstances of the case.

results.ground_truth: Penalty points are recorded on your driving licence when: You are convicted in court of a driving offence that attracts penalty points or You pay a fixed charge notice that was issued to you for an offence that also carries penalty points If you get 12 penalty points in any 3 year period, you are automatically disqualified from driving for 6 months. Learner permit drivers are disqualified if they have 7 penalty points. This lower threshold also applies for the first 2 years of a driver’s first full driving licence. Penalty points are not added to your licence immediately. Fixed charge and penalty offences Fixed notice penalties are issued for driving offences that attract penalty points and/or just a fine. If you receive a fixed notice penalty, you will be issued a notice by the Department of Transport. If you pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a further notice from the Department of Transport confirming that the penalty points will be added to your driving licence. The penalty points will be added to your licence 28 days after that. If you do not pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a summons to appear in the District Court. If you are convicted of a driving offence in court, the court will notify the Department of Transport of the number of penalty points attached to that conviction. The Department of Transport will then issue a notification that these penalty points will be added to your driving licence 28 days after the notification date. You can get information on fixed charge notices and fines in our document on driving offences.

Example 3:
Q: How do penalty points work?
A:
Penalty points on your driving licence occur when you receive a fixed-term driving offence point from the Road Traffic Act 1961. Each point represents a violation of a traffic law, such as speeding, failing to stop at a red light, or running a red light. To remove these points, you must complete a minimum number of hours of approved training courses, known as a Rehabilitation Unit Course (RU). The specific details about how many hours of training are required can vary depending on your local authority or road safety body. After completing the course, you will need to pay any outstanding fines associated with the offences leading to the points, which may include court fees and possible additional penalties. It's important to note that the process of removing points varies by region, so it's advisable to check with your local authority for the most accurate information regarding your area's requirements.

Example 3:
Q: How can I comment on a planning application?
A:
To comment on a planning application in Ireland, you will typically need to follow these steps:

1. **Find the Planning Application**: Locate the specific planning application you wish to comment on by checking the official Irish Government website or relevant local authority portal. Ensure you have the correct reference number associated with the application.

2. **Gather Information**: Collect any relevant information about the proposed development, such as its location, size, nature, and impact. This might include photographs, detailed descriptions from the developer or local authorities, and any other supporting documentation.

3. **Prepare Your Comment**: Write a clear and concise letter outlining your comments. Start with a brief introduction stating who you are and why you are commenting. Then explain the issues you have identified regarding the planning application. Be objective and factual, avoiding emotional language. Provide evidence or references where possible to support your points.

4. **Submit Your Comments**: Send your comments via email directly to the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage (DHLGH). The email should clearly state "Planning Application" in the subject line and contain your full name, contact details, and the reference number of the planning application. Attach all relevant documents and copies of your comments.

5. **Follow Up**: After submitting your comments, it’s advisable to send a follow-up email to confirm receipt and to check the status of your comments. Keep track of the response period specified by the DHLGH and ensure your comments are reviewed promptly.

By following this structured approach, you can effectively communicate your views on a planning application, contributing positively to the decision-making process. Remember, providing constructive feedback is crucial in ensuring the planning process reflects the community's interests and needs. 

This structured approach ensures clarity and professionalism in your comments, increasing their likelihood of being considered by the appropriate authorities. It also demonstrates your commitment to responsible land use and urban planning practices. Always respect legal requirements and guidelines set by the relevant government bodies. If you encounter any difficulties during the process, consider consulting with local experts or legal advisors to ensure compliance with all regulations. By taking these steps, you contribute to the efficient and fair administration of the planning system in Ireland.

results.ground_truth: Citizens Information Services (CISs) provide face-to-face services to the public. Through trained staff and volunteers, CISs provide free, impartial and confidential information, advice and advocacy services to the public. Each Citizens Information Service covers a geographical area and delivers the service through a network of Citizen Information Centres (CICs). There are eight individual regional Citizens Information Services which are companies limited by guarantee and are registered charities. They cover the following areas: North Dublin, Dublin South, North Connacht and Ulster, North Leinster, North Munster, South Connacht, South Leinster and South Munster facilitating both rural and urban areas. Q: What is respite care?
A:
Respite care refers to temporary breaks from regular caregiving responsibilities. It allows family members or caregivers to take time off to rest, recharge, or engage in activities they enjoy. Respite can be provided by various means, including paid services like home health aides, personal care attendants, or day programs, or unpaid volunteers who offer assistance. The primary goal of respite care is to reduce caregiver burnout and improve overall well-being through periodic relief. Examples include allowing someone else to visit the elderly person in their home on a regular basis, hiring a companion service, or participating in a local support group where participants share experiences and strategies for managing caregiving demands. This type of care is crucial for maintaining the physical and emotional health of both the caregiver and the person receiving care.

Q: What is a medical card?

A medical card, also known as a health card or NHS card in some countries, is a document issued by the National Health Service (NHS) of the United Kingdom to eligible individuals who wish to access healthcare services through the national system. To obtain a medical card, applicants must meet certain eligibility requirements such as being registered with a general practitioner (GP), having no outstanding debts related to healthcare, and meeting any additional criteria specified by local authorities. It allows users to visit GP surgeries, pharmacies, and hospitals without needing to pay upfront costs for most services, making it easier to manage their healthcare needs efficiently. For further information on obtaining a medical card, interested parties should consult official NHS websites or contact their nearest local authority office directly.

results.ground_truth: Pre-nuptial agreements have no basis in law in Ireland. As a result, they are not strictly binding. This means that if you have a pre-nuptial agreement in place and you end up in court following the breakdown of your marriage, the judge is not bound by the terms of the pre-nuptial agreement. The only provision in Irish law is under sections 113 and 113A of the Succession Act 1965 (as amended) where a spouse or a civil partner can renounce his/her legal right share in a pre-nuptial agreement. Although they are not legally binding, there is nothing in Irish law which stops a couple planning to marry from having and signing a pre-nuptial agreement. Importantly, such agreements can serve as guides for the courts in judicial separation and divorce cases. If a pre-nuptial agreement makes ‘proper provision’ for each person it is more likely to be persuasive on the judge. Therefore, in situations where one party is likely to inherit a significant family farm or business, it will guide the judge in the divorce or judicial separation on what the parties’ intentions were at the outset.

Example 3:
Q: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?
A:
Pre-nuptial agreements, also known as "prenups," are contracts between spouses before marriage that set forth their respective rights and obligations regarding property division in case of divorce or death during the marriage. They can be legally binding if they comply with specific Irish laws on marriage and family affairs. However, pre-nuptial agreements are not universally recognized across all jurisdictions; they may vary significantly by country. In Ireland, while there isn't a blanket prohibition against them, courts generally interpret such agreements cautiously due to concerns about fairness and equity. To ensure legality and enforceability, it's advisable to consult with a lawyer specializing in matrimonial law. 

In summary, pre-nuptial agreements are legally significant but require careful drafting and court scrutiny to be enforceable. Legal advice is crucial for navigating these complex issues.

Pre-nuptial agreements, also known as "prenups," are contracts between spouses before marriage that set forth their respective rights and obligations regarding property division in case of divorce or death during the marriage. They can be legally binding if they comply with specific Irish laws on marriage and family affairs. However, pre-nuptial agreements are not universally recognized across all jurisdictions; they may vary significantly by country. In Ireland, while there isn't a blanket prohibition against them, courts generally interpret such agreements cautiously due to concerns about fairness and equity. To ensure legality and enforceability, it's advisable to consult with a lawyer specializing in matrimonial law. 

In summary, pre-nuptial agreements are legally significant but require careful drafting and court scrutiny to be enforceable. Legal advice is crucial for navigating these complex issues.

results.ground_truth: The Department of Transport regulates air transport. This includes commercial and private services. EU airlines can fly freely within the EU/European Economic Area (EEA). They can do this without any restrictions on flight frequency or routes. Airlines from countries outside of the EU/EEA must request permission. They must do this each time they want to fly to, from, or over Ireland. The Department of Defence regulates military air transport in Ireland.

Q: What criteria do I need to meet to qualify for unemployment benefits in Ireland?
A: You must be under 66 years of age, or under 70 years and deferring your State Pension (Contributory), be unemployed (you must be unemployed for at least 4 days out of 7), have had a substantial loss of employment and as a result be unemployed for at least 4 days out of 7 (this does not apply to casual workers and part-time fire fighters), be capable of work, be available for and genuinely seeking work, and have enough social insurance (PRSI) contributions.

Example 3:
Q: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?
A:
Aviation in Ireland is regulated by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The CAA oversees all aspects of aviation operations, including safety standards, airport management, air traffic control, and regulatory compliance. They also ensure that airlines adhere to European Union regulations and international aviation protocols. Their primary goal is to maintain public safety while ensuring efficient and fair operation of the Irish aviation sector. This includes overseeing licensing requirements for pilots, aircraft maintenance, and conducting regular inspections of airports and facilities to guarantee they comply with aviation safety guidelines. The authority employs inspectors who conduct audits and investigations into incidents involving aviation activities to promote continuous improvement in safety measures across the industry. In summary, the Civil Aviation Authority plays a crucial role in regulating aviation in Ireland, focusing on safety, efficiency, and adherence to international standards.

results.ground_truth: Under the Cycle to Work Scheme (also known as the Bike to Work Scheme), you can get a new bike tax free through your work. Your employer pays for a new bike and then you repay the cost of regular instalments from your gross (overall) salary. You do not have to pay tax, PRSI or the Universal Social Charge on your repayments. Not every employer takes part in the scheme. However, if they do, they must offer it to all their employees. If you are self-employed, you cannot take part in the Cycle to Work Scheme unless you pay PRSI as an employee in addition to your self-employed work.
results.question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?

Q: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?
A:
The Cycle to Work Scheme allows people who are over 18 years old to purchase a new cycle with no upfront costs by claiming tax-free money from their employer. The maximum value of a cycle purchased through this scheme is €500. The scheme covers all types of cycles, including bicycles, tandems, trikes, recumbent bikes, motorbikes, motorcycles, scooters, and e-bikes. To participate, individuals must meet certain eligibility criteria, such as being able to demonstrate they will use the cycle regularly and safely for commuting purposes. They also need to complete an application form and provide evidence of their employment status and ability to claim tax-free allowances. The scheme is administered by Transport Infrastructure Ireland (TII) on behalf of the Department of Transport, Tourism and Sport.

results.ground_truth: Operating hours vary by stop and direction of service. You can view Luas operating hours and Luas frequency on luas.ie. There are electronic displays telling you the time of the next tram at every Luas stop. In addition, there are electronic displays and announcements informing passengers of the next stop on board every tram. Special services operate during Christmas, New Year and on other occasions.

Q: What are the operating hours and frequency of the Luas?
A:
The Luas operates from Monday to Saturday, with service disruptions on Sundays. The service runs every 5 minutes during peak times and every 8-10 minutes during off-peak times. Peak times typically occur between 9 am and 6 pm, while off-peak times are generally before 9 am and after 6 pm. Additionally, there are occasional weekend services on Saturdays and Sundays depending on the day and time of travel. To check real-time schedules and any delays, passengers can use the Luas App or visit the Dublin Bus website.
